results.headline: Strung Out and Baked in Veracruz

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Artificial Paradises

results.summary_short: “Paraísos Artificiales” watches as a heroin addict and a marijuana enthusiast hang out in a Mexican beach town.

results.headline: Who’s the Most Self-Absorbed of Them All?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mirror Mirror

results.summary_short: The Snow White character in “Mirror Mirror” deviates only a bit from the heroine of the classic tale. This time Lily Collins is armed and suited for action.

results.headline: Swimming With Devils in the Deep

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark Tide

results.summary_short: In “Dark Tide” Halle Berry plays a shark whisperer with a past who is commissioned to take a client out to swim with the great whites.

results.headline: A Brawler With a Soft Side

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goon

results.summary_short: In “Goon,” Seann William Scott plays a hockey enforcer in a minor-league team, a raging beast when dispatched onto the ice, but a shy, courtly lug outside the rink.

results.headline: Best Friends Rolling in the Hay (and in Flour, Too)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Four Lovers

results.summary_short: Two French couples swap partners, and everything seems just as it was in “Four Lovers,” which was originally titled “Happy Few.”

results.headline: You Can’t Always Clone What You Want

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Womb

results.summary_short: A woman seeks to recreate her lost lover in “Womb” by becoming his mother.

results.headline: In Paradise, and Closer Than Ever to Disaster

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Island President

results.summary_short: In “The Island President,” the documentary filmmaker Jon Shenk turns his camera on the uglier realities of life and politics in the Maldives.

results.headline: A Heart Needs One Thing, Society Wants Another

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Deep Blue Sea

results.summary_short: “The Deep Blue Sea” is based on Terence Rattigan’s play about a woman’s attempt to live by the dictates of her heart rather than the expectations of society.

results.headline: A Deadbeat, He’ll Never Live Up to His Name

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Trouble With Bliss

results.summary_short: Michael Knowles’s film “The Trouble With Bliss” follows a 35-year-old who lives with his father and does very little, except attract women.

results.headline: Bad Guys Upstairs, Gore Down the Hall

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Raid: Redemption

results.summary_short: “The Raid: Redemption,” written and directed by Gareth Huw Evans, tells of a police action against a crime lord, complete with meticulous and bloody fight scenes.

results.headline: Tested by a Picturesque Dystopia

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hunger Games

results.summary_short: Jennifer Lawrence stars as a teenage survivalist in a recycled American frontier myth in “The Hunger Games,” a film adaptation of the Suzanne Collins novel.

results.headline: Proof That Science Can’t Find You Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Losing Control

results.summary_short: In “Losing Control,” a Harvard doctoral student tries to make life choices using charts and experiments, with expected results.

results.headline: A Documentary in Which All Bets Are Good Ones

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All In: The Poker Movie

results.summary_short: “All In: The Poker Movie” provides a history of the game but is mostly a defense of online gambling.

results.headline: The World Is Ending; Check Your To-Do List

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 4:44 Last Day on Earth

results.summary_short: “4:44 Last Day on Earth,” Abel Ferrara’s new film, offers an intimately scaled view of the destruction of the world.

results.headline: Teenagers Perplexed About Faith and Sexuality

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wise Kids

results.summary_short: “The Wise Kids” is an exploration of the growing pains of Christian teenagers in a Baptist church in Charleston, S.C., who confront uncertainties about their sexuality and faith.

results.headline: Seeking a Father, Finding Humanity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Kid with a Bike

results.summary_short: With “The Kid With a Bike,” Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne tell a secular parable of compassion.

results.headline: The Family That Squabbles Together

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reuniting the Rubins

results.summary_short: Yoav Factor’s “Reuniting the Rubins” looks at relatives who really don’t get along.

results.headline: The Grind House of My Father

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Casa De Mi Padre

results.summary_short: In “Casa de Mi Padre,” Will Ferrell speaks Spanish, rides horses and gets naked, while Diego Luna and Gael García Bernal rock ’70s duds.

results.headline: A Gang War in the Future

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The FP

results.summary_short: “The FP” portrays two gangs battling in Frazier Park, Calif.

results.headline: A Man Who Spewed His Seed Finds the Son Who’s No Prize Crop

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Natural Selection

results.summary_short: Rachael Harris stars in “Natural Selection,” Robbie Pickering’s debut feature about a woman who sets out to find her husband’s son.
